awd_titl_txt: OCE PRF Track 2 (International):  Tracking mesopelagic carbon flux and particle size on a multi-ocean scale using a fleet of bio-optical profiling floats
awd_abstract_narration:
The sinking of organic carbon through the mesopelagic ocean (100-1000 meters) represents an important long-term sink for atmospheric carbon dioxide and a carbon source for deep-sea and benthic ecosystems. Research results from this project will make a significant contribution to the science of carbon flux, which is important both for improving climate projections and understanding deep ecosystems. The project was submitted to the Ocean Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowship program and will further the career of a promising scientist. Given the global nature of studying carbon flux in the mesopelagic, the fellow is being hosted by Hervé Claustre at the Laboratoire d'Oceanographie de Villefranche(LOV) in France and building strong international collaborations to improve understanding on this internationally important topic. This award was supported with funding from the Office of International and Integrative Activities.

Temperate and subpolar phytoplankton blooms account for large amounts of mesopelagic carbon flux. Mesopelagic flux patterns may change considerably in the future due to climate change, potentially causing climate feedbacks and/or threatening deep ecosystems. Current technologies for measuring mesopelagic flux are logistically challenging, involving the retrieval of physical samples. Current methods are also difficult to compare, due to differing sampling scales and methods. In this project, the fellow will increase coverage of mesopelagic flux measurements during high-latitude phytoplankton blooms by applying novel methods the fellow developed during graduate studies to a large "Bio-Argo" float dataset. The flux dataset produced as a result of this project will be of great benefit to the scientific community, allowing broad analysis of global patterns in addition to the intensive, region-specific flux studies undertaken using traditional methods. By identifying broad-scale patterns in flux and their drivers, this work will increase knowledge of the regions studied and help satellite oceanographers and modelers test and improve flux products. Furthermore, as the Bio-Argo fleet expands to form a permanent, global network, this work will form the start of something bigger: a global, in situ flux record. As such, methodological lessons learned during analysis of this project will inform future sampling strategies and validation efforts, helping to ensure the quality of this global record.

por.por_cntn:
This project used a new and rapidly growing robotic technology called autonomous underwater profiling floats to advance our knowledge of carbon cycling in the ocean. The most significant new finding was that the fragmentation of large, fast-sinking particles in the ocean is a critical control on the amount of carbon that is transported to the deep ocean by marine life. This carbon transport is vital to our planet for two reasons: it is the main source of food for the vast and enigmatic deep ocean ecosystems, and it is also responsible for long-term (1000s of years) removal of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. Previous studies had found that less carbon reaches the deep ocean (1 km depth) than expected, given the speed of sinking "marine snow" particles that carry the carbon and the speed that animals and bacteria in the ocean's "twilight zone" (0.1 to 1 km depth) consume that carbon. They hypothesized that fragmentation of these particles was slowing them down and giving them more time to be consumed. Using new technology in unexpected ways, we obtained results that strongly support this hypothesis. A fleet of more than 40 robotic profiling floats moving autonomously between 1 km depth and the surface in the cold an harsh regions of the subpolar North Atlantic ocean and the Southern Ocean tracked the concentrations of both millimeter-sized fast-sinking marine snow particles and smaller, slower particles over three years using simple optical sensors. We found strong evidence that, during intense spring and summer "marine snow" events, associated with high carbon transport, roughly 50% of the marine snow particles that were lost in the "twilight zone" ended up fragmented into smaller particles.
